bibl.title: Letter from H.F. Moore to Henry Rose Carter, January 29, 1915

div1.p: Moore informs Carter that it is feasible to ship mosquito-eating fish to Alabama. The Bureau of Fisheries will cooperate with the Public Health Service.

div1.head: Letter from H.F. Moore to Henry Rose Carter, January 29, 1915
div1.opener:
EH-2
RSF
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO
COMMISSIONER OF FISHERIES
WASHINGTON, D. C.
DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE
BUREAU OF FISHERIES
WASHINGTON
January 29, 1915.
Dr. H. R. Carter, Asst. Surgeon-General,
United States Public Health Service,
Treasury Department,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of January 26, in reference to
a supply of mosquito-eating fishes by this Bureau, I beg to
advise you that it probably will be feasible to ship such fishes
to the northern part of Alabama, notwithstanding that the distance
is somewhat greater than that which was mentioned in the Bureau's
letter of December 6 to the Surgeon-General. If a number of
shipments can be combined so as to make the aggregate sent to one
region of sufficiently large quantity, a messenger can be sent
with it to insure that the fishes will be properly cared for en
route. This would materially increase the radius of supply
from any particular station. In this event it would be advisable
to have somebody on hand at each center of distribution to take
immediate charge of the consignment and see that the fish are
planted without delay.

It is not believed that the carp is as bad as its reputation
for spawn eating but undoubtedly it does consume some eggs and,
under conditions where the other food is limited, probably eats
them in large numbers. Your reasoning in regard to the de-
sirability of Gambusia for stocking ponds in which carp occur
-2-
appears, therefore, to be sound.

It is probable that all sunfish when young feed more or less
extensively on mosquito larvae and some of the smaller species
persist in this habit through life. The Bureau would be able
to supply considerable numbers of young fish for stocking ponds
inhabited by predaceous species and as most of the sunfishes are
desirable for food, a double purpose would be served.

The Bureau would be glad to cooperate with the Public Health
Service in any way possible.

I am enclosing herewith a circular on mosquito-eating fishes
which perhaps you may not have seen. This circular is available
for distribution to all applicants.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, H. F. Moore
Deputy Commissioner. Enc.
